Description: Students learn both online and in-person, in which both learning enviroments are connected to provide an integrated learning experience, and with some element of student control over the time, place, path, or pace of learning.

The school's model is designed to ensure students are becoming proficient by advancing on demonstrated mastery. May include a deliberate focus on student agency, transparent learning expectations, timely/differentiated supports, varied pacing and pathways, meaningful and formative assessment.

The school designs for and with historically marginalized students, with the goal of improving experiences, supports, and outcomes for these students, who may include: students with learning differences, students in foster care, students in the justice system, students with low academic performance, students from historically disenfranchised racial and cultural groups.

The school defines student success beyond traditional measures such as GPA, and assesses students along the expanded definition of success. (May include career readiness, social-emotional skills, purpose and agency, etc.)
The school is building a culture of taking direct action to counter and dismantle policies and practices that create or perpetuate inequality between racial groups.
Students learn through answering complex questions or solving for real-world problems. Also called problem-based learning, inquiry-based learning, or learning-by-doing.

The school has a comprehensive strategy to support students' social and emotional development (e.g. self-management, social awareness, relationship skills, etc), which manifests across curriculum, school culture, classroom management, discipline, and behavior expectations.

Dialogue circles are gatherings in which all participants sit in a circle facing each other to facilitate open, direct communication. They provide a safe, supportive space where all school community members can talk about sensitive topics, work through differences, and build consensus.
The school offers (or partners to offer) social and wraparound support services to families and the community at large, e.g. through adult learning, childcare, family counseling, financial advising.
Pedagogy and curriculum are continually adapted to be relevant to the cultural environment and background of students attending the school.

Restorative practices are used to resolve conflict and strengthen relationships among individuals and within communities. (In contrast to reacting to harmful or hurtful behavior with punishment or suspension.)
The school integrates social and emotional learning throughout the academic curriculum (in contrast to a stand-alone SEL curriculum).
The school has adopted a formal classroom curriculum for social and emotional learning outside of academic subjects.

Tag name: assessments for social-emotional skills and school climate
Description: The school uses strategies to assesses school climate, social-emotional, and noncognitive skills e.g. self-management, social awareness, relationship skills, belonging, etc.
The school offers (or partners to offer) comprehensive counseling and mental health services for students.
The school offers (or partners to offer) comprehensive services to support the physical health and well-being of students, e.g. supports related to nutrition, housing, abuse, bullying.

Adults in the school community are trained to recognize and respond to those who have been impacted by traumatic stress, and students are provided with clear expectations and communication strategies to guide them through stressful situations.

Tag name: reallocation of resources for those most in need
Description: Example: assigning most experienced and highest skilled teachers to students needing the most help.

Hiring practices are designed to result in new hires with equity-focused values. The school may employ specific innovations such as: students or community members on the interview committee, equity and positionality rubrics in use, hiring pool stays open until qualified diverse candidates are indentified.
The school is open outside of normal hours and during vacations to support learning and offer services.
Students plan and lead a meeting including parents and teachers to discuss the student's learning and growth. (As opposed to parent-teacher conferences without students present.)

The school uses a social justice lens to design curriculum, instruction, policies, and community engagement. This could include work to understand and address large, complex social issues such as poverty, food insecurity, racism, and environmental justice.
A form of bilingual education in which students are taught literacy and content in two languages.

The school involves families in shared decision-making, and communicates how family input has informed decision-making. This may include strategies such as participatory budgeting, family advisory groups, etc.

Tag name: projects as primary method of learning
Description: Projects are a central approach to learning core content and skills, rather than added on as extra activities once core content is covered.

Projects and learning activities develop knowledge and skills across multiple subject areas and highlight connections between subject area domains, with formal collaboration among teachers across subject areas.
Students engage in design thinking, a structured framework for identifying challenges, gathering information, generating potential solutions, refining ideas, and testing solutions.
Students engage in meaningful community service to enrich the learning experience, learn civic responsibility, and strengthen their communities.

Tag name: portfolios and public exhibitions of student work
Description: Students collect and share evidence of their work over time to demonstrate their learning and growth, and independently present their projects, reflect on their learning, and share progress towards their goals for an audience.
Note: Gregor: can this be a combination of "portfolios" and "exhibitions" from 2019 (if either is yes, this 2020 tag is yes)?

Description: Student projects involve action steps to solve or meaningfully improve real-world problems (e.g. homelessness in their city, or a marketing challenge faced by a real company).
Students are partners and leaders in designing, implementing, and assessing projects.
Students can access a space and/or set of tools for use in building and designing creations.
The school uses local knowledge, skills, issues, heritage, culture, and landscapes as the foundation for studying subjects across the curriculum.
The school creates deliberate structures and processes for peer support, e.g. peer mentorship, peer tutoring, accountability partners, etc.
The school assesses deeper learning and 21st century skills beyond academic content mastery, e.g. communication, collaboration, critical thinking', etc.
Students can demonstrate mastery in multiple ways (e.g. portfolio, oral presentation, test, group project, etc).
The school makes creative use of human capital, e.g. through a tutor residency model, outside experts, master teachers or teacher mentors, etc.
Design maximizes for flexibility and student choice, e.g. multi-purpose spaces, moveable walls, furniture can be arranged in different configurations, etc.

Tag name: real time data use to drive instruction
Description: The school has created systems and routines to continuously monitor progress and tailor learning activities.
Students rotate through stations on a fixed schedule, where at least one of the stations is an online learning station.

Students rotate through online and other stations on individual schedules set by a teacher or software algorithm. Students do not necessarily rotate to every station; they rotate only to the activities scheduled on their playlists.
Students rotate through stations on a fixed schedule, where at least one of the stations is an online learning station located in a dedicated computer lab.
Students learn at home via online coursework and lectures, and teachers use class time for teacher-guided practice or projects.

Students move on fluid schedules among learning activities according to their needs. Online learning is the backbone of student learning, and teachers provide support and instruction on a flexible, as-needed basis.
Data from multiple platforms or software programs is integrated in a "data dashboard" reflecting overall student learning and progress.
Content is adapted to individual learners (may be accomplished using adaptive learning software).
Students (and families) can access their own learning and assessment data in real time.
Grades are reported on a standards-based report card, and focus on the specific competencies students are expected to develop.
The school allows students to complete assessments when they are ready, rather than all at once on a fixed schedule.
A transparent learning framework is used to align learning and assessment. What proficiency looks like at each performance level is available to students and families.
Students advance to new topics when they have demonstrated mastery of previous competencies, rather than advancing with only a minimal passing grade.
Students have more than one opportunity to demonstrate their learning in order to show they have achieved mastery.
In assessments, students apply knowledge or demonstrate a skill rather than selecting a correct answer on a test.
Students determine their own pace in learning rather than being required to move at the same pace as a whole group.
Students set and pursue their own learning goals, as well as self-assess their progress.

The school designs learning experiences to proactively meet the needs of all learners by identifying barriers to learning in the design of the environment, not in the student. This helps educators differentiate to effectively instruct a diverse group of students, regardless of whether students have an Individualized Education Program (IEP).
Note: Demoted to Tier 2 tag (was T1 in 2019)

Description: Accommodations traditionally reserved for students with an IEP are available to all students.
Profiles extend across multiple years of school and may include how the student is performing, as well as personal factors like who they are, what inspires them, and how they best learn.

The school involves teachers in shared decision-making, and communicates how teacher input has informed decision-making. Teachers make decisions in areas such as school success, curriculum, budget, evaluating their colleagues, selecting personnel, and more.
The school offers career-oriented learning opportunities, e.g. career tech and vocational training, interview practice, internships and apprenticeships, etc.
The school has developed partnerships with businesses and the community, which may help facilitate experiential learning, internships, mentorships, etc.
Students can access credit-bearing learning experiences outside of the school (e.g. internship, service learning, training, etc).
Students complete the majority of coursework online at home or outside of school, but attend school for required face-to-face learning sessions with a teacher.
Students take an online course with an online teacher in addition to other face-to-face courses.
Students identify and follow unique learning pathways that are relevant to their interests and passions.
The school assesses students' readiness to enter the workforce and pursue a career path.
The school brokers connections between students and industry professionals, including methods such as job shadows, video chats, etc.

Students can earn industry-issued or recognized credentials as a verification of a their qualifications or competence, in fields such as agriculture, hospitality & tourism, health, information technology, etc.
The school offers students the option to take college credit-bearing courses before entering college.
The school is a hybrid of high school and college, where all students take both high school and colleges classes simultaneously, earning credit towards a college degree.

Gifted programs are eliminated and barriers to advanced courses (e.g. AP, IB, honors) are removed so that no student is barred from accessing these opportunities. Remediation takes place throughout the regular scope and sequence so that "lower level" classes are removed.
Small groups of students meet regularly (daily or weekly, over multiple years) with adult advisors to set learning goals, reflect on progress, and build positive relationships.
The school connects students with adults in and outside of the school for 1:1 mentoring and regular check-in meetings.
Classrooms include students of many ages, rather than grouping them by age or grade band.

The school provides tutoring services to students. This may involve a partnership with an outside organization, or utilization of human resources beyond teachers, such as non-instructional staff, parents, or students.
Some students learn fully remotely, such as at home (no core instruction required at school).
Some students learn fully at school (no core instruction required remotely or at home).
Some students learn partially at home and partially at school (core instruction occurs in both settings).
The school uses a rotating schedule to reduce total number of students on campus during in-person learning.
Some students attend school in the morning and others in the afternoon.
Some students attend school one day, and others the next.
Some students attend school one week, and others the next.

families can choose instructional modality teachers can choose instructional modality synchronous online learning asynchronous online learning virtual enrichment activities remote accommodations at-home learning supports digital materials print materials
Teachers can opt into their instructional modality of choice (e.g. fully remote, fully in-person, or hybrid)
Online learning activities occur synchronously, where consistent groups of students participate at the same designated time.
Online learning activities occur asynchronously, where consistent groups of students participate on their own time when they choose.
Beyond core academics, the school the school engages students in enrichment activities while learning remotely.
The school offers special education services to students learning remotely.
The school offers guidance and training for families about how to support students learning remotely.
For remote learning, curricular materials are hosted and distributed digitally.
For remote learning, curricular materials are printed and distributed physically.

Schools seek to remove barriers to student success by locating, partnering, coordinating, and helping students access comprehensive services that complement and are aligned with effective instruction.
The school makes creative use of staffing, systems, and resources to support student-centered learning.
Students have ownership over their learning by setting learning goals, initiating action toward those goals, and reflecting on their growth.
Students learn through real-world experiences inside and outside the classroom (e.g. internships and apprenticeships, service projects, projects in the community, career training).
Students learn through the creative process of design, resulting in either physical or digital creations.

Tag name: hiring practices in support of student success
Description: The school's hiring process prioritizes candidates who bring mindsets that all students can succeed at the highest levels regardless of prior performance.
Teachers develop assignments and learning experiences that are relevant to students' interests and contextualized to their lives.
The school assesses students' development of purpose and agency.
The school allows students to take home school-owned devices.

Tag name: access to information in multiple formats
Description: Teachers offer students access to information and materials in multiple formats e.g. print, online, video, audio, hands-on, etc.
The school goes above and beyond to support immigrant and refugee students through additional resources and creative approaches.

Tag name: supports for high-poverty and homeless students
Description: The school goes above and beyond to support high poverty and homeless students through additional resources and creative approaches.
The school goes above and beyond to support English Language Learners through additional resources and creative approaches.
A non-traditional approach to schedule that aligns with the school's mission and goals.
The school has adopted high quality instructional materials (e.g. green rating on EdReports or equivalent)
Design and innovation prioritizes the needs of historically marginalized students and families. Marginalized people are leaders, participants, and beneficiaries in the design process.
Data analytics are accessible to teachers, understandable by teachers, and are used by teachers to inform instruction.

Tag name: commitment to equity in strategic plan
Description: The school's strategic plan includes an explicit commitment to equity including clear goals, a plan to meet them, methods of assessing progress, and accountability to marginalized students and families.

Tag name: supports for students off-track for graduation
Description: The school goes above and beyond to support students off-track for graduation through additional resources and creative approaches.
The school has a coherent strategy for delivering core curriculum using free, open resources.
Students independently present their projects, reflect on their learning, and share progress towards their goals for an audience.
Local learning serves as a model for understanding global challenges, opportunities, and connections.
The school uses measures for school climate/culture to learn how students experience the school culture.

Tag name: commitment to whole child or SEL in strategic plan
Description: Development of the whole child and social-emotional competencies are a core part of the school's strategic plan.
The school uses measures for students' readiness to enter and complete college.
For example: ensuring marginalized students are receiving appropriately challenging material; recruitment of underrepresented students for AP or IB courses.
